The term ‘pot du vin’ has the undertones of a bribe in modern French. At this period the system of offering and receiving gifts was an informal but yet powerful way of building alliances or reacting to demands from an overlord. The system was thoroughly embedded in public life particularly in the wealthy and influential towns of the Low Countries. Further discussion of this topic can be found in Alain Derville, (19760 ‘Pots du Vincadeaux, racket, patronage: essai sue les mécanismes de décision dans l’état bouguignon’
